name: Test
body:
## Plot Types
Five plot types of original ggplot2 are supported in ggplot2.sparkR now. More types will be updated.
Since the usage of ggplot2.sparkR is exactly the same with origin ggplot2.sparkR, we could click following links to reference them in the original ggplot2 documentation.

### Geoms
Geoms, short for geometric objects, describe the type of plot you will produce.
* [geom_bar](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/geom_bar.html)
* [geom_bin2d](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/geom_bin2d.html)
* [geom_boxplot](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/geom_boxplot.html)
* [geom_freqpoly](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/geom_freqpoly.html)
* [geom_histogram](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/geom_histogram.html)

### Statistics
It’s often useful to transform your data before plotting, and that’s what statistical transformations do.
* [stat_bin](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/stat_bin.html)
* [stat_bin2d](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/stat_bin2d.html)
* [stat_boxplot](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/stat_boxplot.html)
* [stat_sum](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/stat_sum.html)

### Scales
* [scale_x_log10](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/scale_continuous.html)
* [scale_y_log10](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/scale_continuous.html)
* [labs](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/labs.html)
* [xlab](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/labs.html)
* [ylab](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/labs.html)
* [xlim](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/xylim.html)
* [ylim](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/xylim.html)

### Coordinate Systems
* [coord_cartesian](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/coord_cartesian.html)
* [coord_flip](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/coord_flip.html)

### Facets
* [facet_grid](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/facet_grid.html)
* [facet_null](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/facet_null.html)
* [facet_wrap](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/facet_wrap.html)

### Position Adjustment
* [position_dodge](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/position_dodge.html)
* [position_fill](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/position_fill.html)
* [position_stack](http://docs.ggplot2.org/current/position_stack.html)

## Examples
The parameter **_data_** in examples can be either R data.frame or Spark DataFrame.

If the input data is Spark DataFrame, heavyweight data processing stages are offloaded to the Spark backend using the SparkR API.

### 1. geom_bar
Bars, rectangles with bases on x-axis

```R
ggplot(data, aes(x = Item, fill = Payment)) + geom_bar()
```
![image of bar chart](https://moonkyung.github.io/Test/bar.png)

### 2. geom_histogram
Histogram. Bars, rectangles with bases on x-axis using continuous data.

```R
ggplot(data, aes(x = Price)) + geom_histogram(binwidth = 10)
```
![image of bar chart](https://moonkyung.github.io/Test/hist.png)

### 3. stat_sum
Sum unique values. Useful for overplotting on scatterplots.

```R
ggplot(data, aes(x = Item, y = Payment)) + stat_sum()
```
![image of bar chart](https://moonkyung.github.io/Test/stat_sum.png)

### 4. geom_bin2d
Add heatmap of 2d bin counts.

```R
ggplot(data, aes(x = Item, y = Price)) + geom_bin2d()
```
![image of bar chart](https://moonkyung.github.io/Test/bin2d.png)


### 5. geom_boxplot
Calculate components of box and whisker plot.

```R
ggplot(data, aes(x = Item, y = Price)) + geom_boxplot()
```
![image of bar chart](https://moonkyung.github.io/Test/box.png)
